misconceptions.inferred_category_name: No conceptual/logic error (correct parallel-array sort and selection)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the `scores` array while swapping the corresponding `names` elements will keep the two arrays aligned, and that after sorting ascending, the top student is at index `n-1`.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: No gap detected: this matches Java’s execution model and the required parallel-array behavior. Bubble sort swaps both arrays consistently, producing aligned sorted data.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: No error for valid inputs (N>0, correct counts of names/scores). Produces correct output for the sample and the stated requirements.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes there will always be at least one student, so it’s safe to access index n-1 and run loops that use n-1 without checking for n == 0.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-indexed and require valid indices. If n == 0, the arrays have length 0, so accessing a[n-1]/b[n-1] becomes a[-1]/b[-1], which throws an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException. Correct programs either constrain inputs (explicitly require N ≥ 1) or handle the empty case separately.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) when N == 0; otherwise produces correct output for N ≥ 1.
